title: Chapter 12 – Loops and Iteration Patterns Checkpoint
description: Quick concept-check for chapter 12. Test your understanding of for loops, while loops, range(), and iterating over strings and lists.

questions.prompt: What is a for loop mainly used for in Python?

options.label: To repeat code for each item in a sequence.

explanations.overview: for loops are used to repeat code for each item in a range or collection.

byOptionId.a: Functions are defined with def, not with for.
byOptionId.b: Correct – for loops go through each item in a sequence.
byOptionId.c: You would use exit() or similar to stop a program, not for.
byOptionId.d: Variables can be created anywhere, not just in for loops.

explanations.overview: range(stop) starts at 0 and goes up to stop-1.

byOptionId.c: This includes the stop value, which range() does not do.
byOptionId.d: range(3) makes a sequence, not a single number.

questions.prompt: When does a while loop stop running?

options.label: When Python decides it is enough.
Only when the user presses a key.

explanations.overview: while keeps looping as long as its condition is True.

byOptionId.a: A while loop does not magically stop after 10 loops unless you code it that way.
byOptionId.b: Correct – you must make sure the condition can eventually become False.
byOptionId.c: Python does not auto-stop your loops for you.
byOptionId.d: User input can affect the condition, but it is not required.

questions.prompt: Which mistake can easily create an infinite while loop?

options.label: Forgetting to change the variable used in the condition.

explanations.overview: If the condition never becomes False, a while loop never stops.

byOptionId.a: Using a for loop will not automatically make an infinite loop.
byOptionId.b: Correct – if you never update the variable, the condition may stay True forever.
byOptionId.c: Printing a lot is noisy but not infinite by itself.
byOptionId.d: range() is not used directly in while loops.

options.label: Causes an error; you can't loop over strings.

explanations.overview: Strings are sequences of characters, so for can loop over each character.

byOptionId.a: The loop variable ch is a character, not a number here.
byOptionId.b: Correct – ch will be 'c', then 'a', then 't'.
byOptionId.c: Python allows you to loop over strings.
